body_html:
It looks like @IgorX2 had same issue in #8845. I reproduced his error too with his data. His thread references #7856, which has the following workaround posted by @mrry on 26 Feb

Unfortunately TensorBoard uses a colon as the separator between the optional "run name" and the path in the --logdir flag. That means that --logdir=E:\tmp\tensorflow\mnist\logs is interpreted as a run named E with path \tmp\tensorflow\mnist\logs, which explains why it's sensitive to the current working directory.
As a quick workaround, you could avoid this problem by always specifying an explicit run name as part of the --logdir flag, e.g.:

tensorboard --logdir=training:E:\tmp\tensorflow\mnist\logs

(Reassigning to @dandelionmane, who shows up on the blame for the relevant code.)

This workaround worked for me. It seems to be a valid bug and the workaround seems valid. I hope this helps others trying to get this running in windows. At a minimum, perhaps put a note in the tutorial for windows users to specify the explicit run name too?

Very exciting stuff you guys are working on! Hate to see others get slowed down if a simple fix would work.

Very exciting stuff you guys are working on!  Hate to see others get slowed down if a simple fix would work.
body:
It looks like @IgorX2 had same issue in #8845.  I reproduced his error too with his data.   His thread references #7856, which has the following workaround posted by @mrry on 26 Feb

>Unfortunately TensorBoard uses a colon as the separator between the optional "run name" and the path in the --logdir flag. That means that --logdir=E:\tmp\tensorflow\mnist\logs is interpreted as a run named E with path \tmp\tensorflow\mnist\logs, which explains why it's sensitive to the current working directory.
>As a quick workaround, you could avoid this problem by always specifying an explicit run name as part of the --logdir flag, e.g.:

>`tensorboard --logdir=training:E:\tmp\tensorflow\mnist\logs`

>(Reassigning to @dandelionmane, who shows up on the blame for the relevant code.)

This workaround worked for me.  It seems to be a valid bug and the workaround seems valid.   I hope this helps others trying to get this running in windows.  At a minimum, perhaps put a note in the [tutorial](https://www.tensorflow.org/get_started/summaries_and_tensorboard) for windows users to specify the explicit run name too?  

Very exciting stuff you guys are working on!  Hate to see others get slowed down if a simple fix would work.
